question: The House of Lords can overrule the House of Commons
options: Yes, the House of Lords have more powers than the House of Commons

question: Who was Britain's first woman Prime Minister?
tip: Margaret Thatcher was the first woman Prime Minister.

question: As long as you live in United Kingdom you can vote in any elections
What is the title of the Queen's eldest son, Prince Charles?
Where is Loch Lomond located?
tip: Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park: This national park covers 720 square miles (1,865 square kilometres) in the west of Scotland. Loch Lomond is the largest expanse of freshwater in mainland Britain and probably the best-known part of the park.

question: What prehistoric village (off the north coast of Scotland) has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age?
tip: Skara Brae on Orkney, off the north coast of Scotland, is the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe, and has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age.

question: When were the last Welsh rebellions defeated?
tip: By the middle of the 15th century the last Welsh rebellions had been defeated. English laws and the English language were introduced.

question: British values and principles are based on history and traditions.
tip: British society is founded on fundamental values and principles, which are based on history and traditions and are protected by law, customs and expectations.

question: Who was elected as British Prime Minister in 1945?
Which TWO members of a family have a special day dedicated to them?
tip: In the UK Mothering Sunday is celebrated on the Sunday three weeks before Easter and Father's Day on the third Sunday in June. Children send cards and give gifts on these days.

question: Who is the St Patron of England?
tip: St George is the St Patron of England.

question: People living in the UK must pay tax on which of the following TWO?
options: Income from property, savings and dividends
tip:
People in the UK have to pay tax on their income, which includes:
- Wages from paid employment
- Profits from self-employment
- Taxable benefits
- Pensions
- Income from property, savings and dividends.

question: The UK government has never suspended the Northern Ireland Assembly.
Who was John Constable?
options: An important contributor to the 'pop art' movement of the 1960s
A Welsh artist, best known for his engravings and stained glass
A very successful Northern Irish portrait painter
A landscape painter, most famous for his works of Dedham Vale on the Suffolk-Essex border in the East of England
tip: John Constable (1776-1837) was a landscape painter most famous for his works of Dedham Vale on the Suffolk, Essex border in the east of England.

question: Who appoints the members of the cabinet?
tip: The Prime Minister appoints about 20 senior MPs to become ministers in charge of departments which together form the cabinet.

question: The best-known work of ______ is probably the song Auld Lang Syne, which is sung by people in the UK and other countries when they are celebrating the New Year
Patron saints' days occur in March are:
How many national parks are there in England, Wales and Scotland?
tip: There are 15 national parks in England, Wales and Scotland. They are areas of protected countryside that everyone can visit, and where people live, work and look after the landscape.

question: Pantomime productions are staged in theatres during ______
Famous British authors includes:
Who wrote The Bruce about the Battle of Bannockburn?
How old do you have to be to buy alcohol in the UK?
Magistrates usually work unpaid and do not need legal qualifications.
tip: Magistrates and Justices of the Peace (JPs) are members of the local community. In England, Wales and Scotland they usually work unpaid and do not need legal qualifications.

question: If you are resident in the UK, your car or motor cycle must be registered at the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA)
options: No, if you buy a used car, you don't have to register it

question: How many times did Sir Jackie Stewart win the Formula 1 championship?
tip: Sir Jackie Stewart (1939–) is a Scottish former racing driver who won the Formula 1 world championship three times.

question: Magna Carta was important because
options: it established a new system of free education
it limited the power of the monarch
it gave all men the vote

question: Where are minor criminal cases in England, Wales and Northern Ireland heard?
tip: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, most minor criminal cases are dealt with in a Magistrates’ Court. In Scotland, minor criminal offences go to a Justice of the Peace Court.

question: Which architectural style are the famous London buildings of the 19th century, such as the House of Parliament and St Pancras Station, associated with?
tip: In the 19th century, the medieval ‘gothic’ style became popular again. As cities expanded, many great public buildings were built in this style. The Houses of Parliament and St Pancras Station were built at this time, as were the town halls in cities such as Manchester and Sheffield.

question: Which of the following is an example of civil law?
options: To sell tobacco products to anyone under the age of 18
To buy alcohol for people who are under the age of 18
To carry a weapon of any kind, even if it is for self-defence

question: Organ donation in the UK is
options: compulsory required when you apply for a driving license

question: Forcing another person to marry is
options: only allowed if they are cousins

question: Dundee and Aberdeen are cities in Northern Ireland.
tip: Dundee and Aberdeen are cities in Scotland.

question: What did the UK heavily rely on during the industrial revolution?
tip: Scientific discoveries, such as James Watt's work on steam power, helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution.

question: Wales wasn’t under Anglo-Saxon rule
tip: Parts of the west of Britain, including much of what is now Wales, and Scotland, remained free of Anglo-Saxon rule.

question: What county is 'Maiden Castle' in?
tip: A very impressive hill fort can still be seen today at Maiden Castle, in the English county of Dorset.

question: People living and working in towns after Black Death led to the development of what?
tip: Following the Black Death, the smaller population meant there was less need to grow cereal crops. There were labour shortages and peasants began to demand higher wages. New social classes appeared, including owners of large areas of land (later called the gentry), and people left the countryside to live in the towns. In the towns, growing wealth led to the development of a strong middle class.

question: One TV licence covers all of the equipment at one address, but people who rent different rooms in a shared house must buy a separate TV licence
tip: One TV licence covers all of the equipment at one address, but people who rent different rooms in a shared house must buy a separate TV licence

question: In Scotland, serious cases are heard in a ______ with either a sheriff or a sheriff with a jury
People vote in elections at
Can the anthem 'God save the queen' be played only in presence of the queen?
tip: You can play the anthem in anyone's presence.

question: Which of the following is a famous Stone Age site in the UK?
tip: Stonehenge is a famous Stone Age site in Wiltshire. It was probably built as a place for religious ceremonies.

question: Which TWO are part of the Government?
tip: In the UK, there are several different parts of government. The main ones are: the monarchy, Parliament (the House of Commons and the House of Lords), the Prime Minister, the cabinet, the judiciary (courts) ,the police, the civil service, local government.

question: The National Assembly has ______ Assembly members
‘Great Britain’ and ‘the United Kingdom’ have the same meaning
tip: The official name of the country is the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. ‘Great Britain’ refers only to England, Scotland and Wales, not to Northern Ireland.

question: How are civil servants appointed and what political party do they belong to?
options: They are chosen on merit and form part of the Liberal Democrats party
They are chosen randomly and form part of the Conservative party
They are chosen randomly and are politically neutral
They are chosen on merit and are politically neutral

question: When did the English defeat the Spanish Armada, which had been sent by Spain to conquer England and restore Catholicism?
Citizens of the United Kingdom, the Irish Republic, or the Commonwealth, aged ______, may stand for public office
In which part of the British Empire did the Boer War of 1899–1902 take place?
tip: The Boer War took place in South Africa between the British army and the Boer settlers, who originally came from the Netherlands.

question: The murder of Franz Ferdinand in 1914 led to the start of which world war?
tip: On 28 June 1914, Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria was assassinated. This set off a chain of events leading to the First World War (1914-18).

question: Does the British government have a written constitution?
